metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Competitive enzyme inhibitors and the lock-and-key mechanism

lock-and-key.name: Lock-and-Key Model
lock-and-key.correct: The lock-and-key model proposes that substrate fits precisely into the enzyme's active site like a key in a lock

enzyme changes shape completely.fix: Lock-and-key assumes rigid, pre-formed complementary shapes

any substrate can fit any enzyme.fix: Only substrates with correct shape fit the active site

the lock is the substrate.fix: Enzyme is the lock (fixed); substrate is the key (fits into it)
the lock is the substrate.action: Enzyme active site = lock; substrate = key

persistent.gap: Not understanding lock-and-key as shape complementarity
persistent.action: Active site shape precisely matches substrate shape

enzyme-substrate-complex.name: Enzyme-Substrate Complex
enzyme-substrate-complex.correct: Substrate binds to active site forming enzyme-substrate complex, then products are released

enzyme is permanently changed.fix: Enzyme is released unchanged and can catalyse more reactions
enzyme is permanently changed.action: E + S → ES → E + P; enzyme recycled

binding is irreversible.fix: ES formation is reversible; substrate can dissociate without reacting
binding is irreversible.action: Equilibrium between E + S and ES

products stay bound.fix: Products have different shape and leave the active site
products stay bound.action: Product release allows next substrate to bind

persistent.action: Enzyme binds substrate, catalyses reaction, releases product, repeats

competitive-inhibition.name: Competitive Inhibition
competitive-inhibition.correct: Competitive inhibitors bind to the active site, competing with substrate for the same binding location

binds elsewhere on enzyme.fix: Competitive inhibitors bind AT the active site, blocking substrate
binds elsewhere on enzyme.action: Competitive = active site; non-competitive = different site

permanently destroys enzyme.fix: Inhibitor binding is reversible; high substrate can overcome it
permanently destroys enzyme.action: More substrate can outcompete the inhibitor

has completely different shape from subs.fix: Competitive inhibitors have similar shape to substrate to fit active site

persistent.action: Similar-shaped inhibitor blocks substrate from active site

inhibitor-structure.name: Inhibitor Structure
inhibitor-structure.correct: Competitive inhibitors structurally resemble the substrate to fit the active site

any molecule can inhibit.fix: Only molecules with complementary shape to active site can bind
any molecule can inhibit.action: Inhibitor must fit the lock just like the substrate key

larger molecules are better inhibitors.fix: Shape complementarity matters most; size must match active site
larger molecules are better inhibitors.action: Must fit active site, not just be large

inhibitors are always synthetic.fix: Many competitive inhibitors are natural products or derived from them
inhibitors are always synthetic.action: Both natural and synthetic competitive inhibitors exist

persistent.gap: Not connecting inhibitor structure to mechanism
persistent.action: Structural similarity to substrate allows active site binding

reversibility.name: Reversibility of Inhibition
reversibility.correct: Competitive inhibition is reversible; increasing substrate concentration can overcome inhibition

inhibition is always permanent.fix: Competitive inhibitors bind reversibly via non-covalent interactions
inhibition is always permanent.action: Inhibitor can unbind; substrate can then bind

more inhibitor always wins.fix: High substrate concentration can outcompete inhibitor for active sites
more inhibitor always wins.action: It's a competition: more substrate = less inhibition

maximum velocity cannot be reached.fix: With enough substrate, Vmax can be reached despite inhibitor
maximum velocity cannot be reached.action: Competitive inhibition increases Km but doesn't change Vmax

persistent.action: Substrate and inhibitor compete; excess substrate overcomes inhibition

drug-design.name: Drug Design
drug-design.correct: Many drugs work as competitive enzyme inhibitors, blocking enzymes involved in disease

all drugs are enzyme inhibitors.fix: Many drugs work by other mechanisms (receptor binding, etc.)
all drugs are enzyme inhibitors.action: Enzyme inhibition is one important drug mechanism among many

inhibiting any enzyme is therapeutic.fix: Drug must inhibit specific disease-related enzyme without affecting others
inhibiting any enzyme is therapeutic.action: Selectivity is crucial to avoid side effects

drugs bind permanently.fix: Reversible binding allows dose adjustment and cessation

persistent.gap: Not connecting enzyme inhibition to drug action
persistent.action: Drugs can block disease-related enzymes by competitive inhibition

examples.name: Inhibitor Examples
examples.correct: Statins inhibit cholesterol synthesis enzyme; many antibiotics inhibit bacterial enzymes

only one class of drugs uses inhibition.fix: Many drug classes use enzyme inhibition: statins, antibiotics, antivirals, etc.
only one class of drugs uses inhibition.action: Enzyme inhibition is widespread in pharmacology

inhibitors are toxic.fix: Selective inhibition of disease-related enzymes is therapeutic, not toxic
inhibitors are toxic.action: Correct target = medicine; wrong target = poison

examples are only synthetic.fix: Penicillin (natural antibiotic) is a competitive enzyme inhibitor
examples are only synthetic.action: Natural and synthetic enzyme inhibitors both used as drugs

persistent.gap: Not knowing examples of enzyme inhibitor drugs

selectivity.name: Enzyme Selectivity
selectivity.correct: Effective drugs selectively inhibit target enzymes without affecting similar enzymes elsewhere

selectivity doesn't matter.fix: Non-selective inhibitors cause side effects by affecting non-target enzymes
selectivity doesn't matter.action: Selectivity = efficacy with minimal side effects

all enzymes are equally affected.fix: Active sites differ; inhibitor binds best to target enzyme
all enzymes are equally affected.action: Design inhibitors to fit target but not similar enzymes

perfect selectivity is easy.fix: Achieving high selectivity is a major drug design challenge
perfect selectivity is easy.action: Related enzymes may have similar active sites

persistent.gap: Not understanding selectivity importance in drug design
persistent.action: Good drug: high target inhibition, low off-target effects

sentences.text: The lock-and-key model compares the enzyme's {0} site to a lock and the {1} to a key.
In this model, the substrate has a {0} shape that fits precisely into the {1} shape of the active site.
When substrate binds to enzyme, an {0}-{1} complex forms. This then breaks down to release {2} and regenerate the enzyme.

questions.tooltip: Substrate binds to form ES complex

sentences.text: A competitive inhibitor has a similar {0} to the substrate and binds to the {1} site.

questions.tooltip: Competitive inhibitors bind AT active site

sentences.text: When the inhibitor occupies the active site, the {0} cannot bind, so the {1} is slowed.
Competitive inhibition is {0} because increasing {1} concentration can overcome the inhibition.
Many drugs work as {0} enzyme inhibitors, blocking enzymes involved in {1}.
Effective enzyme inhibitor drugs must be {0}, affecting the target enzyme without inhibiting {1} enzymes.
Statins are competitive inhibitors of HMG-CoA {0}, an enzyme involved in {1} synthesis.
The lock-and-key model explains enzyme {0}: only substrates with the correct {1} can fit the active site. A different substrate is like a wrong {2} that doesn't fit the lock.

questions.tooltip: Wrong key won't fit the lock

sentences.text: The enzyme-substrate complex is held together by {0} interactions between the substrate and amino acids in the {1} site. These include hydrogen bonds, ionic interactions, and {2} forces.
A competitive inhibitor resembles the {0} closely enough to fit the active site, but unlike the substrate, it doesn't undergo the {1} reaction. It just {2} the site.

questions.tooltip: Inhibitor is not converted to product

sentences.text: With competitive inhibition, {0} substrate concentration can restore enzyme activity because substrate molecules can {1} inhibitor molecules for active site {2}.

questions.tooltip: Numbers game: more substrate = more binding
They compete for same binding site

sentences.text: The effect of competitive inhibition on enzyme kinetics: the apparent {0} increases (harder to saturate enzyme), but maximum {1} remains unchanged (at high substrate, inhibition is overcome).

questions.tooltip: Vmax unchanged; just need more substrate

sentences.text: Penicillin is a competitive inhibitor of the bacterial enzyme {0}. This enzyme is essential for building bacterial cell {1}. Without it, bacteria cannot {2}.
Drug designers analyse the {0} of the target enzyme's active site. They then design molecules with complementary {1} that will bind tightly but not be processed as {2}.

questions.tooltip: Design shape to fit active site

sentences.text: Selectivity challenges: human and bacterial enzymes may have {0} active sites. An antibiotic must bind bacterial enzyme but not the {1} human equivalent.

The lock-and-key model was proposed by Emil Fischer. While useful, it has been refined by the {0} fit model, which recognises that active sites can undergo {1} changes upon substrate binding. Both models emphasise {2} complementarity.

When the enzyme-substrate complex forms, the substrate is held in the optimal {0} for the reaction. Functional groups in the active site may participate in {1}. After reaction, products have {2} shape and leave the active site.

questions.tooltip: Products don't fit well, so they leave

sentences.text: Comparing substrate and competitive inhibitor: both have {0} shapes that fit the active site. The substrate is converted to {1}; the inhibitor is {2}. This means inhibitor occupies the site without productive reaction.
Methotrexate is a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate {0}, an enzyme essential for {1} synthesis. Cancer cells need rapid DNA synthesis, so inhibiting this enzyme slows {2} growth.

The drug design process for competitive inhibitors: (1) identify disease-related {0}, (2) determine active site {1}, (3) design molecules that fit the site but aren't {2}, (4) test for {3} (binding target vs others).

questions.tooltip: Know the active site in detail

sentences.text: HIV protease inhibitors are competitive inhibitors that block viral {0} processing. They resemble the natural {1} sequence that the protease normally cleaves. By blocking this enzyme, new virus particles cannot {2}.

explanations.lock-and-key: The lock-and-key model proposes rigid complementary shapes between enzyme active site (lock) and substrate (key).
explanations.enzyme-substrate-complex: Substrate binds to active site forming ES complex, then products are released and enzyme is recycled.
explanations.competitive-inhibition: Competitive inhibitors bind to active site, blocking substrate; similar shape to substrate required.
explanations.inhibitor-structure: Competitive inhibitors structurally resemble substrates to fit and block the active site.
explanations.reversibility: Competitive inhibition is reversible; high substrate concentration can outcompete inhibitor.
explanations.drug-design: Many drugs work as selective competitive enzyme inhibitors targeting disease-related enzymes.
explanations.examples: Statins (cholesterol), antibiotics (bacterial wall), antivirals (viral processing) use competitive inhibition.
explanations.selectivity: Effective drugs selectively inhibit target enzymes without affecting similar enzymes, minimising side effects.
